Add first-pass 'promote' functionality

Previously the "promote" subcommand was called "patch".  I thought this could
lead to some confusion.  Typically the source file in a "patch" operation
remains untouched by the patching process (and can be reverted and re-done if
necessary.  However, that's not what happens here.  The idea is to "promote"
(move) settings from the local file to a default file.  And in this case, we
don't want the local file to retain the same settings as the default file (as
that could mask further changes made via version control; the assumption here
is that 'default' is version controlled.)  Therefore, the rename "promote"
seemed more appropriate.

Add support for the 'unarchive' command

Created code for the 'unarchive' command.  It supports extracting from both
compressed tarballs (.tar.gz/.tgz/.spl) as well as extracting zip files.
Both install and upgrade operations are supported and automatically detected.
When the destination is a git working tree then a reasonable attempt is made
to make sure the destination is clean to prevent loss of local work.
Several sanity checking levels exist to vary how strict the clean check is.
Also, there are several git modes where the user can control is the app is
simply extracted to the working tree, if the working tree changes should be
staged, and if the staged changes should be automatically committed.

Additionally, the unarchive command supports:  (1) Renaming of the app being
installed.  (A few automatic renaming rules are in place, but primarily this is
a CLI feature.)  (2) Exclusion rules for unwanted content (3) Support for app
that ship with "local" files, (4) renaming of the 'default' folder, this if for
use with the 'ksconf combine' mode.

More work on the 'unarchive' subcommand is likely, but this seems good enough
for a first pass.

Add conf parsing profiles, a container class, and argparse integration

Updated the parse_conf() interface to accept a 'profile' instead of passing
around a dozen individual parser settings all the time.  For the moment, this
is still implemented as a simple Python dictionary, but eventually this will be
swapped out when the parser itself is overhauled.

Introduced a new 'ConfFileType' class that works as an argparse argument 'type'
that allows an easier integration with with the cli implementation code.  For
example, it's now possible to hand-off simple conf file validation steps to
this new class and therefore skip duplicate implementations of the traditional
"can't read file", and "can't parse file" checks.  Now when either of these
conditions occur, the user is prompted with an error message back from argparse
(before custom CLI code is even called) and consistently across subcommands.

The ConfFileType class works by passing ConfFileProxy objects to the CLI
implementation functions.  These classes also store the appropriate parsing
profile because it's often desirable to vary the parsing features depending on
the nature of the subcommand.  This proxy class provides a simple interface for
reading and writing Splunk .conf files.  Also, because some commands, such as
'minimize' allow a directory to be indicated, instead of a single conf file,
the ConfDirProxy class was created.

Return codes for several subcommands have been tweaked.  This still needs more
work but should at least be a step in the right direction.

Add 'rest-publish' command

Supports:

- Pushing multiple stanzas to a specific config endpoint at once, in a fairly
  efficient process.
- Changes made on the server are show in the form of a diff.  (Eventually, this
  should be configurable, and a dry-run mode should be added.)
- Supports pushing to a live Splunk instance (via Splunkd REST API).  This
  should replace the use of 'rest-export' for MOST use cases.
- Supports reading and applying metadata (ACLs, owner, shared, app) to imported
  objects.
- Any type of conf entry should be supported.

Limitations:

- **NO UNIT TESTING!**  (This will require some fancy mock work.)
- Doesn't support attribute-level metadata.
- No SSL validation setup yet.  This is primarily because of how Splunk's
  Python SDK works.  For other Python HTTP libraries this is enabled by default.
